displayed_text: Family Member: It’s still two years. So you don’t gain any time. Doctor: We don’t think so. Patient: What if we had castrate level Doctor: Quite frankly, we’re too nervous to you know; the first thing we’re trying to do is cure you. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And uh they were pretty; um, the lab studies were done in two years were sort of a minimum time in this setting. Family Member: So in other words this third option, the chemo and the hormones—so when the chemo ends he’ll be getting radiation while he continues to get the hormone therapy. Doctor: Yeah and we give the chemo and the super hormones for three months. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then give you about time to recover about six to eight weeks later. Then we do the radiation, uh which puts you at about sort of eight months, you know out, so then you’d have another; it’s a total of two years of hormones. Patient: Okay and then how frequently will my PSA be tested while I’m doing the chemo? Doctor: Every month.

Patient: Uh well like one of them know about you know my surgery, but you know sometimes you know I don’t feel comfortable talking to some people about what I been… Doctor: I understand, right, I understand. Patient: You know and… Doctor: So. Patient: You know I’m just, I’m glad to be alive. (Laughs) Doctor: Right. Patient: <___> what I’m sayin’. Doctor: Right. To try to speed this along I think I’ll refer you to Dr. L____. He’s our person here who takes care of sexual dysfunction. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: Uh Because uh you know it seems like that certainly is something that concerns you very much. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: And so…

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There could either be zero or there could be some somewhere. It’s just not enough for it to be detectible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So therefore getting a CAT scan, bone scan, it doesn’t, it’s kind of a waste of time because even if something’s there it’s not enough to actually be seen. Family Member: Be seen, okay. Doctor: On a scan. Family Member: So it doesn’t mean there’s nothing there, it just means it won’t be picked up. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Okay. Patient: And I’ll I think my last PSA was somewhere like around three five, three six something like that. Now what value or number would you consider going in towards scans? Doctor: One or two. Patient: Okay.
